articles.headline: Upgrading to Lion Means Embracing the iPad
articles.snippet: Apple applies its “shake things up” policy in its new version of Mac OS X 10.7, known as Lion. It shares two important factors with the iPad.
articles.abstract: Apple applies its “shake things up” policy in its new version of Mac OS X 10.7, known as Lion. It shares two important factors with the iPad.
articles.lead_paragraph: It must be excruciating to design a new version of an already mature operating system. How do you add enough new stuff to attract upgrade customers — without junking up the works? And how do you revamp enough things to make the upgrade exciting — without alienating people who don’t like change?

articles.headline: Despite Risk, Embalmers Still Embrace Preservative
articles.snippet: While the chemical was recently labeled a carcinogen, undertakers insist nothing else preserves the body well enough for public viewing or for shipping.
articles.abstract: While the chemical was recently labeled a carcinogen, undertakers insist nothing else preserves the body well enough for public viewing or for shipping.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the government declaring formaldehyde a carcinogen, these might be boom times for alternative embalming fluids — if it weren’t for the so-called everlasting effect funeral directors stake their reputations on.

articles.headline: Push Intensifies for Larger Deal on Debt Impasse
articles.snippet: As compromises took shape on both sides, President Obama and Congressional leaders sought to resurrect a sweeping agreement on a plan to cut the deficit and raise the debt ceiling.
articles.abstract: As compromises took shape on both sides, President Obama and Congressional leaders sought to resurrect a sweeping agreement on a plan to cut the deficit and raise the debt ceiling.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the clock ticking down, President Obama and Congressional leaders began a final effort to forge a broad deficit-reduction plan even as new cracks appeared among House Republicans over how to proceed.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Social Media History Becomes a New Job Hurdle
articles.snippet: A start-up helps companies dig into potential employees’ activity online, from Facebook posts to e-commerce usage.
articles.abstract: A start-up helps companies dig into potential employees’ activity online, from Facebook posts to e-commerce usage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Companies have long used criminal background checks, credit reports and even searches on Google and LinkedIn to probe the previous lives of prospective employees. Now, some companies are requiring job candidates to also pass a social media background check.

articles.headline: As Rivals Stir, Romney Sticks to Playing It Safe
articles.snippet: As the Republican presidential campaign intensifies, Mitt Romney’s determinedly low-key approach could be fraught with peril.
articles.abstract: As the Republican presidential campaign intensifies, Mitt Romney’s determinedly low-key approach could be fraught with peril.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tim Pawlenty forged ahead on an 18-city tour across Iowa, a dawn-to-dusk schedule of courting voters. Michele Bachmann released a new television ad warning against raising the nation’s debt limit. And Gov. Rick Perry of Texas inched even closer to entering the presidential race, inviting top-shelf donors to Austin.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jennifer Medina

articles.headline: Wheeling and Dealing
articles.snippet: At next week’s contract talks, carmakers and the United Automobile Workers union will square off over how to divide the profits of Detroit’s unexpectedly swift revival.
articles.abstract: At next week’s contract talks, carmakers and the United Automobile Workers union will square off over how to divide the profits of Detroit’s unexpectedly swift revival.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — American carmakers and the United Automobile Workers union open contract talks next week with a common task of preserving the comeback of an industry that was on the verge of collapse just two years ago.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Wall St. Makes Fallback Plans for Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: Lawmakers in Washington are racing to reach a deal to save the country from defaulting on its debt, but financial players are devising doomsday plans in case the clock runs out.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers in Washington are racing to reach a deal to save the country from defaulting on its debt, but financial players are devising doomsday plans in case the clock runs out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in Washington are racing to reach a deal to save the country from defaulting on its debt, but on Wall Street, financial players are devising doomsday plans in case the clock runs out.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Scalping Battle Putting ‘Fans’ in the Middle
articles.snippet: Ticket sellers are setting up nonprofit groups that claim they represent consumers, but are part of a lobbying fight over control of the multibillion-dollar secondary ticketing market.
articles.abstract: Ticket sellers are setting up nonprofit groups that claim they represent consumers, but are part of a lobbying fight over control of the multibillion-dollar secondary ticketing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s the summer concert season and, as usual, many fans are frustrated that rampant ticket scalping online has made seeing their favorite performer almost as much a frustration as a thrill. But now a new group says it wants to help.

articles.headline: Heads of Europe Back Broad Plan to Rescue Greece
articles.snippet: The rescue package of 109 billion euros, or $157 billion, reduces Greece’s debt burden in a last-ditch effort to preserve the euro and stem a broader financial panic.
articles.abstract: The rescue package of 109 billion euros, or $157 billion, reduces Greece’s debt burden in a last-ditch effort to preserve the euro and stem a broader financial panic.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of resistance, European leaders agreed Thursday to reduce Greece’s debt burden in a last-ditch effort to preserve the euro and stem a broader financial panic.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Stephen Castle
